definitions.definition: an act of injecting somebody with a drug or other substance
definitions.labels: (British English)(informal)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(British English)(British English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(British English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(British English)

examples.text: to **give somebody an injection**
He was treated with penicillin injections.
daily injections of insulin
An anaesthetic was administered **by injection**.
In some US states execution is by **lethal injection**.
Both groups received a second injection with the same solution.
Can I bring my dog in for his booster injection?
He had to have a tetanus injection after injuring himself with a shovel.
The best treatment is antibiotics, preferably by injection.
The rats received a daily injection of the drug.
They gave her an injection to stop the pain.
an injection against whooping cough
an injection into the vein
injections for diabetes

definitions.definition: a large sum of money that is spent to help improve a situation, business, etc.

examples.text: The theatre faces closure unless it gets an urgent cash injection.
The company had reached the size where it needed an injection of capital.
The infrastructure requires a massive cash injection.
a cash injection from the Belgian state
an injection of cash into the economy

phrases: an injection of capital, cash, resources, etc.

definitions.definition: an act of forcing a liquid or other substance into something

examples.text: a 2-litre direct injection engine

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin injectio(n-), from the verb inicere, from in- ‘into’ + jacere ‘throw’.
